fields.description:
*Environment*

_Eucalyptus Version_

{{4.4.0-0.25734.119.20170117git96ba726.el7}}

_Setup_

# Created federated setup with two Eucalyptus clouds
#* [hspencer-240-maint-4.4|http://jenkins.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com/job/Quick%20Launch%20Maint_4.4/240/] - single AZ
#* [hspencer-243-maint-4.4|http://jenkins.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com/job/Quick%20Launch%20Maint_4.4/243/] - multiple AZ

*Assessment*

While using {{UpdateStack}} on a deployed stack, it was noticed that the stack status never reached {{UPDATE_COMPLETE}}.  This was discovered while doing multiple tests of EUCA-11897 which scaled out an ASG and ELB to another AZ, then scaled back in with another {{UpdateStack}} call.  
{code}
[root@d-02 ~]# euform-describe-stacks --region devops-admin@future
STACK	DevOpsNginxStack	UPDATE_IN_PROGRESS	User Initiated	CloudFormation template to launch a highly available Nginx web stack with ELB access logging in Eucalyptus VPC	2017-01-27T17:07:18.176Z
PARAMETER	ImageId		emi-6b3768f5
PARAMETER	KeyName		devops-admin
PARAMETER	InstanceType		m1.medium
PARAMETER	MinSize		2
PARAMETER	MaxSize		4
OUTPUT	AccessLogBucket	devopsnginxstack-s3loggingbucket-ombkfvqgnb8vd
OUTPUT	ELBURL	http://DevOpsNgi-NginxELB-OYXDAHDTLEQST-001095389763.lb.c-29.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com
{code}
Templates to create issue are attached.  Steps for reproduction can be found in EUCA-11897.

*Signs*

fields.summary: UpdateStack stays in UPDATE_IN_PROGRESS due to SWF workflow timeout

comments.body:
Every CloudFormation stack workflow has a timeout of 10800 seconds (3 hours).  The following stack workflows exist:

CreateStackWorkflow
DeleteStackWorkflow

UpdateStackWorkflow
UpdateRollbackStackWorkflow
UpdateCleanupStackWorkflow
UpdateCleanupRollbackStackWorkflow

The workflows above that reference the parts of update stack were split up to simplify the process.

There are two additional workflow types
MonitorCreateStackWorkflow
and
MonitorUpdateStackWorkflow

these constantly monitor the state of the stack and call rollback or delete operations if the stack fails.

Both Monitor operations also check for timeout of the main operations, but for 'create' it is much more likely to occur, as create timeout is a parameter passed in via the command line.

The Monitor workflows are kicked off at the same time as the Create and Update workflows.  If the Create and Update workflows timeout naturally, the monitor workflows will likely timeout at the same time, so they won't detect timeout in the other workflows.  There are no monitoring workflows for delete or the other portions of the update workflow.

One way to deal with this issue right now would be to increase the monitor workflow timeouts beyond the create/update timeouts to allow for the timeouts to be checked.

The main question we want to deal with, however, is how long should our timeout for these actions be?  Is there ever an occasion where 3 hours isn't long enough to create or update a stack?

irc discussion of the above.

ethomas__: sjones4: there is a check on delete stack to see if a stack is not in an UPDATE_IN_PROGRESS state that will not allow it to be deleted.  Perhaps we should add a check to see if the workflow in question has timed out before we disallow delete.
sjones4: ethomas__, generally we should have some "background task" that does clean up for time outs (which could be in addition to the monitoring workflows that catch most cases)
ethomas__:  ok.  If we have implemented child workflows, we may be able to detect timeouts also but you are proposing something that runs constantly (maybe on the clc) and checks general stack status?
sjones4: ethomas__, right. Separate clean up work performed by the service rather than any specific stack that prevents resources getting stuck in whatever state. Could be a timer task, continuous workflow, etc
ethomas__: sjones4: ok.

Looks like the stack can't be 'un-stuck' using {{CancelUpdateStack}} or {{DeleteStack}}:
{code}
[root@d-02 ~]# euform-delete-stack DevOpsNginxStack --region devops-admin@future
euform-delete-stack: error (ValidationError): Stack arn:aws:cloudformation::001095389763:stack/DevOpsNginxStack/b71ec6a8-c769-4ee4-ba3f-615781517ebc is in UPDATE_IN_PROGRESS state and can not be deleted.
[root@d-02 ~]# euform-cancel-update-stack DevOpsNginxStack --region devops-admin@future
euform-cancel-update-stack: error (ValidationError): Unable to cancel update workflow for arn:aws:cloudformation::001095389763:stack/DevOpsNginxStack/b71ec6a8-c769-4ee4-ba3f-615781517ebc
{code}
Are there some other steps that can be done to get the stack removed?  If not, should we raise the urgency of this issue to get it fixed sooner rather than later?

+1 for this one. We have several stacks which have been in various stuck states for several releases now. We have had to resort to removing them directly from the DB. Being able to remove stacks in unhealthy states would be a huge plus.

git branch dev-ethomas-EUCA-13168-merge
git show af7a09971f72de6aa48b67c890a49206303c17d4

This patch addresses the following issues.
1) Workflow timeouts leaving stacks in a stuck state (such as UPDATE_IN_PROGRESS)
2) Being able to delete a stack in a stuck state (such as UPDATE_IN_PROGRESS)

To deal with the first issue:

Originally we had a MonitorUpdateStackWorkflow and a MonitorCreateStackWorkflow to deal with timeouts or cancellations on the CreateStackWorkflow and the UpdateStackWorkflow but their timeouts were the same as the original workflows so that didn't help much.  The first change made was increasing the default timeouts of the Monitor workflows from 10800 to 12600 seconds.

Second, not all workflows had been handled this way.  As such, to make items more uniform, we added MonitorDeleteStackWorkflow, MonitorUpdateCleanupStackWorkflow, MonitorUpdateRollbackStackWorkflow, and MonitorUpdateRollbackCleanupStackWorkflow, to monitor the appropriate other workflows.  On timeout, appropriate 'final' states were set on the stack.  In addition, we added a RollbackStackWorkflow and MonitorRollbackStackWorkflow as well.  Some refactoring was also done due to common logic in the monitoring code.

To deal with the second issue:
Two additional 'delete' modes were added, they are not officially named anywhere, but this is what was used in the code for a 'boolean' value.

forcedDelete -- What happens in this case is that all stack workflows are cancelled, the regular check about not deleting during certain update operations is not performed, then a regular delete operation occurs.  One difference between this and a regular delete operation, however, is that if at the end of the delete process, if there are any resources that failed to delete, the stack is deleted anyway.  In a regular delete process, the stack would be marked DELETE_FAILED.

forcedDeleteNow -- Similar to forced delete, all workflows are cancelled and regular check about not deleting during certain update operations is also not performed, but then a simple resource check is done, and all resources that had not yet been deleted are immediately marked DELETE_SKIPPED and the stack is marked DELETE_COMPLETE.  No workflows are performed, and all work is done in the 'deleteStack()' service method.  (This is similar to the idea of just deleting the stack metadata)

As in 4.4.1 there are no obvious way to pass in non-standard parameters (and even if there were, the tooling may not allow it), I have added the following caveats:

All deletes from a System administrator will be considered as a forced delete of some sort.  There are two configuration properties that are used:

cloudformation.forced_delete_for_admins (default false) --- If this property is 'true', one of the above forced deletion options will occur whenever a system administrator deletes a stack.  If this property is false, the administrator will perform a regular delete, which means for example it will fail if the stack is in the UPDATE_IN_PROGRESS phase.

cloudformation.retain_resources_on_forced_delete (default false) -- This property only matters when cloudformation.forced_delete_for_admins is true.  In that case a 'true' value for this property will use the 'forcedDeleteNow' option for the administator's forced delete.  A 'false' value for this property will use the 'forcedDelete' version.


There may be a better way to pass in --forcedDelete or --forcedDeleteNow options, but this was put out there to have something.  Discussion on better options is welcome.

[~ethomas], I haven't reviewed all the changes, but I think this is too large for 4.4.1. Perhaps for 4.4.1 we could change the monitoring workflow timeouts and consider the remaining items for 5.0.  To update the timeout on upgrade I think you would need to bump the @Execute version for the workflows.
[~sjones]  Thanks for the review.  I will simply extend the timeouts for MonitorCreateWorkflowImpl and MonitorUpdateWorkflowImpl for 4.4.1, and retool the rest for 5.0

[~sjones] Next attempt at review

git branch dev-ethomas-EUCA-13168
git show 7623032ab88f3169e57521d0a4cb4bc99414888e

Used StartTimeoutPassableWorkflowClientFactory for all workflows (currently used for create) to override attribute values for timeout, using attribute values if null, allowing changing attribute values not to affect existing workflows.  Also added time to the MonitorUpdateStackWorkflow to detect timeouts.

[~ethomas], looks good to me.

A couple of (debatable) groovy style preferences:

* when there is a parameter default value defined (e.g. Long executionStartToCloseTimeoutSeconds = null) generally avoid passing the default explicitly when calling the method, i.e. I would remove ", null, null" from calls to getNewWorkflowClient
* use "WorkflowRegistrationOptions" rather than "WorkflowRegistrationOptions.class" for a class reference

Nice work here [~ethomas] and [~sjones].  Fix is money.
